Don‚Äôt go into the Nosferatu remake with high expectations‚Äîunless you‚Äôve seen the 1922 original recently. Without that reference point, it‚Äôs easy to miss how deliberately Eggers mirrors the original, both in composition and in how he contrasts it through grotesque realism. If the silent classic is fresh in your mind, the remake becomes a cinematic dialogue‚Äîa love letter to horror‚Äôs evolution and the art of filmmaking. Watch the original first, then Eggers‚Äô vision, and you‚Äôll better appreciate just how far horror and film as a medium have come: in sound, color, visual effects, and the sheer depth of storytelling. Especially striking is what directors are now able to show audiences in the mid-2020s‚Äîimagery and intensity that would‚Äôve been unimaginable a century ago.

Every aspect of Eggers' Nosferatu is technically excellent, but somewhat ironically, and yet almost appropriately, it lacks the humanity needed to connect the audience to its characters and illicit genuine emotional investment. The acting is excellent, the imagery is amazing, and the score and sound design collaborate to nearly transcendent levels at times. All these immersive elements draw us in to this world with each scene, and I personally find the film to be very re-watchable. Still, I never felt any proper connection to these people, or any real stake (pun intended) in their plight. Much has been made of Eggers' attention to detail, and emphasis on maximum accuracy based on his own extensive research, and while that is immediately evident for the full length of the film's runtime, the parts never add up to more than their sum as they have in his previous works. Flaws aside, it's a really great movie, especially if you enjoy atmospheric gothic horror, and particularly if you appreciate occult accuracy. This one slides easily in the top tier of vampire flicks, and gothic horror, but not quite into the upper echelons of the horror genre more broadly.

An epic disappointment to see this string of "mood scenes" played out with a dreadful screenplay and story trying to resolve the central dependancy relationship between Ellen Hutter and her friends family that supported her. Then shock horror the ending turns into a sort of body-horror relationship after dragging us through many dreary acting scenes along moody shorelines. Keep the moody shorelines and feel but all of the Willem Dafoe shambolic investigation themes, combined with that badly written family friend dependency piece was shockingly poor. I think for me, I would have prefered that family with Aaron Taylor-Johnson to hate on Ellen Hutter earlier, to add more tension. Like he had some sort "buck up your ideas" vibe going on to add more friction earlier, instead of the stagnation and sudden "get away from my family" moment he had near the end. One scene got my energy up, when Thomas Hutter was starting to explore Orloks castle. It had a little bit of tension instead and stopped feeling like a montage adventure for a bit and I think coming back to that explorative tension at different stages could have worked well, without it needing to be a full on action-flic. The director could clearly not do that adventure tension drama and I don't think it would have taken much to add that back in without it turning into every other action-vamp movie.

Surprisingly disappointing given the mostly positive critical response. It's been the first time in memory I've been bored with a film. Since "everyone" knows the Dracula story, remakes would ideally flesh out the possibilities of atmosphere, character and dialogue in creative and deeper ways, making it possible to see this story for something akin to the first time. Nosferatu did the opposite. The vampire character danced with self-parody. His raspy inhalations reminded me immediately of Darth Vader, and I almost laughed. The vampire was largely devoid of personality interest - a monster whose character was revealed right from the start of the film and didn't change or reveal anything more throughout. Nosferatu didn't build suspense and really couldn't since the director decided that he would go full bore on noisy sound effects maximal dramatic tension from the very first scene. Nosferatu revealed a commonplace film-making fallacy: You don't create atmosphere and suspense by following a checklist, which is what this film appears to have done. You do it by careful artistry and attention to psychology and emotion. With any new film that disappoints, I try to not let it become an over-determining bellwether of the state of the film industry. But over the last 12 hours of reflection on Nosferatu, I'm slightly depressed that this film got made, got made the way it did, and had the positive reaction it did. Are we this starved for good movies that we'll put laurels on that which we really know doesn't deserve it? Kudos to the cinematographer, the music director and the actors, but Nosferatu just didn't come together at all. The sensibility of the gothic deserves a better effort than this.

This film is pure gothic horror perfection. Robert Eggers has crafted a haunting, atmospheric experience that lingers long after it‚Äôs over. Bill Skarsg√•rd transforms into Count Orlok with terrifying ease, delivering a performance that‚Äôs both monstrous and eerily human. The cinematography is stunning‚Äîdark, shadowy, and suffocating. Watching the tension build between Orlok and Thomas Hutter‚Äôs wife, Ellen, was deeply unsettling. Every shadow felt dangerous, every glance heavy with menace. The sense of dread was relentless, and by the end, I felt like I‚Äôd survived something truly horrific. If you‚Äôre a fan of slow-burn, atmospheric horror, this is an absolute must-see.

"Nosferatu" (2025) exemplifies the pitfalls of derivative filmmaking, offering a lackluster retelling that pales in comparison to its predecessors. The film's reliance on clich√©d jump scares and uninspired shadow imagery underscores a creative stagnation, failing to capture the profound horror of Bram Stoker's original narrative. A ghastly, gothic, horror film that was long-due to shake the stratosphere. Nosferatu goes back to the roots of horror, in brings back with it, the terror of the fear of the unknown and purely evil in a way not every horror film can. Nosferatu is a re-imagination of a classic, and while the story may be as old as time and numbed down to nothing; Eggers has a way to stunningly deliver peak modern-day filmmaking. Eggers uses sharp sound design, intricate shots, and a menacing dread to embody such a dark and evil film. His vision for how to re-tell the story also emphasizes the end result, giving a more sinister film with even more substance to it. Eggers not only has awakened Nosferatu, but he has also awakened a welcome return of dark, classical horror.

This film is a stunning reimagining of its early, expressionist counterpart, which was itself a notable building block within the film industry as a whole. It is a difficult legacy to live up to, but Robert Eggers manages to pull it off. While maintaining a richly dark and unsettling atmosphere, the cinematography provides a whole new, beautiful direction. Nosferatu not only remains faithful to its predecessor but also elaborates upon its characters, shifting themes and agency to weave dimension in a complex modern reimagining. It is the offspring of gothic film of old and the intricate complexity of present cinema.

Here, he seems distracted by the sets and costumes and the need to make every shot look like a Gothic screensaver. I didn't love some of the casting decisions. Unfortunately, this is well covered ground, and Eggers didn't add much to the vampire myth. A good looking movie, and it has it's moments, but it never really catches fire. I came away disappointed.

Okay, so this wasn‚Äôt exactly my thing, strictly enjoyment-wise. It's a bit of a slow burn, and for someone like me who's not super familiar with the lore of Dracula or the original Nosferatu, I was pretty lost for the first half. It‚Äôs quite atmospheric and full of brilliant cinematography, set design, costumes, and makeup -- definitely Oscar-worthy in those departments. But I was struggling for the first act to find something to sink my teeth into... Enter Willem Dafoe. His character shows up in the second act and, honestly, he brings an energetic shift to the screen and some much-needed exposition, which helped me get my bearings. There are some metaphors or themes lurking under the surface here, if you want to read into that kind of thing. I like Robert Eggers' stuff, and I think this movie is objectively better than my rating suggests, but as far as personal enjoyment goes, this one didn't hit for me. I wouldn‚Äôt rush to recommend it, but I can appreciate the craft.

We once had what was a really alluring dracula character in some of the older films, and now he just represents complete evil. Boring. No point in him being a vampire; like it had pretty much literally nothing to do with the story other than that now sucking blood is also kind of a sexual act, and the whole story of the woman seemed to hinge on her basically having a necrophilia fetish. There are many film reviewers on YouTube and I doubt anyone bothers to watch them all when deciding whether to go to the cinema and watch the latest movie. Me - I have two or three 'trusted' reviewers who, over the years, I've come to find their tastes in movies align with my own pretty faithfully. In short - I trust their opinions. And all three gave 'Nosferatu' glowing reviews. This, coupled with my general love of horror films, made me buy my popcorn and take my seat. Now, you'll have to forgive me for not know too much about how this vampire story came to be, but I believe that it was a deliberate attempt to 'retell' the story of 'Dracula' but the film-makers (in the original and to this day) weren't allowed to use the character names and settings etc. I really enjoyed 1992's 'Bram Stoker's Dracula' and, to put it bluntly, I just felt like I'd rather watch that. I never realised that 'Nosferatu' stuck so closely to the plot of 'Dracula.' Ultimately, what you have here is a beat for beat 'remake' (with a different ending). Therefore, nothing really took me by surprise as I knew where it was going 90% of the time. To be fair, it's filmed well and the sets and general atmosphere are nicely creepy. Plus the actor who plays... oh, whatever they call Dracula in this film, does a great job, so there are definitely plus points. I just found the whole concept of this film redundant as it felt like a poor copy/remake of the 1992 classic. I didn't hate it, but if I'd know this was all it was going to be I'd rather have just put on my DVD of 'Dracula' and saved myself the petrol.

The new Nosferatu reimagines the classic with a hauntingly fresh vision that both pays homage to the original and elevates it to new, chilling heights. The atmosphere is absolutely intoxicating, with stunning cinematography and a score that heightens every moment of tension. The eerie performance by Skarsgard, embodying Count Orlok, is both unsettling and captivating. It‚Äôs a film that manages to be both timeless and contemporary, capturing the essence of silent horror while bringing it into the modern age. Beautifully shot, impeccably acted, and genuinely unnerving ‚Äî this Nosferatu is a masterpiece that will leave you thinking long after the credits roll.

While I can see why some people would appreciate this movie, I am unfortunately not one of them. Don't get me wrong‚Äîthe movie is good, and so are the cinematography, costumes, and choice of background sounds. Mix in a bit of the eerie atmosphere, which this movie definitely does not lack, and you get a pretty good film. Unfortunately, I felt bored on some occasions, as it's quite a lengthy movie for what it's trying to convey. The movie has an antique look to it, but keep in mind that it's modern. You should give it a shot, though‚Äîif not for the story, then for the cinematography.

Robert Eggers fundamentally misunderstands the difference between Dracula and Nosferatu. A remake of a classic film is only justified if the remake adds something new or innovative to the original. Herzog understood this in ‚ÄúNosferatu the Vampyre‚Äù - the most obvious augmentation of Munrau‚Äôs classic being sound and color. Roger Eggers labors under the misapprehension that it is somehow new or innovative to make Nosferatu sexy. To be fair, neither previous Nosferatu is sexy. However, that was a deliberate decision of both Munrau and Herzog. Nosferatu has not been made sexy yet because there is an entire other side of the Stoker vampire archetype that is already sexy - Dracula. Egger‚Äôs integration of sexual themes into Nosferatu is a re-insertion of American Dracula elements that were intentionally excised from Nosferatu by the German masters. The sexuality is neither new nor innovative. It follows that this remake is not justified.

Despite its polished cinematography and strong technical execution, this film ultimately falls flat, failing to bring anything fresh or engaging to the genre. While visually striking, it lacks substance, relying on an overused ‚Äúgood people vs. bad monster‚Äù formula that we‚Äôve seen countless times before. There‚Äôs no depth, no subversion of expectations, and no real reason to invest in the story. The characters feel hollow, their actions dictated solely by the writer‚Äôs need to move the plot forward rather than by any internal motivations or desires. They don‚Äôt evolve, face meaningful struggles, or make compelling choices‚Äîthey simply exist to serve the mechanics of the screenplay. Because of this, the film never feels organic or immersive, instead playing out like a by-the-numbers exercise in genre filmmaking. Ultimately, it‚Äôs a soulless experience. The impressive technical craftsmanship is wasted on a story devoid of tension, intrigue, or emotional weight. It‚Äôs as if the film expects the audience to be dazzled by its visuals alone, ignoring the fact that great storytelling requires more than just spectacle. The result is an utterly forgettable experience, a fanfare of technicality with the flavor of stale soda‚Äîflat, uninspired, and disappointing.

I admit that I can't count myself as a fan of the genre, especially of vampire movies (with exception of non-serial Tony Scott's 1983 "Hunger"), but there really is no one to like this remake, except maybe the fans of bad acting, overlong shots and senseless scenarios, as well as the sympathizers of necrophilia, unnecessary pornographic scenes and vomiting of stomach contents at every godly opportunity. Even the original from 1922 is more watchable than this extremely pretentious version, with an unrealistically inflated rating on official movie sites. Since I'm already of the opinion that this misdeed doesn't even deserve any deeper analysis, I'll take the opportunity to remind the audience of a few much better works on this topic: 1. "Nosferatu: A Symphony of Horror" (1922) - F. W. Murnau 2. "The Fearless Vampire Killers" (1967) - Roman Polanski 3. "Nosferatu the Vampyre" (1979) - Werner Herzog 4. "Hunger" (1983) - Tony Scott 5. "Bram Stoker's Dracula" (1992) - F. F. Coppola
